content: "Cases of waterboarding have occurred on U.S. soil, as well. In 1983, Texas Sheriff James Parker was charged, along with three of his deputies, for handcuffing prisoners to chairs, placing towels over their faces, and pouring water on the cloth until they gave what the officers considered to be confessions. The sheriff and his deputies were all convicted and sentenced to four years in prison". content: Just a simple question, were they convicted of torture or coercing a confession? Would it be torture to inject someone with sodium amytal? It would absolutly be tossed out of court if the confession was obtained this way, and the interogator could be charged as well. I don't want to get into the waterboarding is torture or not. This thread is about waterboarding being a crime. The crime was coercing a confession, not the means. They should have been convicted of the same crime for using a phonebook to extract the confession.
